Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 I hate to break the news, but there is no AS protocol on the planet that u would qualify for. MM,Consult1,Highlander: Deep down I know this to be true. Guess it is, or was, wishful thinking on my part. Remember. I'm the guy that hates going to ER or Dr if having a problem. Not because of what I will find out, but afraid I'm making a big deal over nothing! Drives my wife nuts!!
Posts.Signature: DOB - 07/05/1949 Age-68 PCa Family History - Father, Paternal Uncle (Both died from cardiac issues) PSA- 1997-2013 Gradually increasing from 1.4 - 3.2, PSA 2014 3.5 PSA 2015 4.7 PSA 06/08/2017 8.8 PSA 07/19/2017 9.88 DRE-smooth, normal Biopsy - 08/15/2017 Biopsy results: 9 of 12 cores positive - Gleason 6 - Percent Tumor Involvement 10-95% Left mid Prostate - Adenocarcinoma of prostate. Gleason Score 3+3=6. Involving 10-95% of the length of 5 cores. Right mid Prostate - Adenocarcinoma of prostate. Gleason Score 3+3=6. Involving 25-80% of the length of 4 cores. Perineural Invasion Present. Prostate size 37gm Stage T1c Oncotype Dx Genomic Prostate Score - 10/19/17 - GPS 22 (Low Risk), Prostate Cancer Death within 10 years <1%, Meatastasis within 10 years 1%, Adverse Pathology (Gleason=>4+3 and/or pT3+) 22% MRI scheduled - 12/15/2017
Posts.Title: Biopsy results back - Feel like squirrel crossing busy street

Posts.Content: New to forum, 68 year old here. After many years PSA running up slowly from 1.4 to 3.2, in 2014 at 3.5, and in 2015 4.7. Moved to new state and did not get PSA test until 06/08/2017 which came in at 8.8. Primary Dr referred me to URO who rechecked PSA and came back as 9.88. DRE at that time was normal, but URO recommended biopsy which I had done on 08/15/2017. Received call from URO on 08/21/2017 asking me to come in to review results from biopsy. Results from biopsy were (see signature for full report) I did indeed have PCa. Good news was that all cores came back at 3+3=6. Areas of concern were that PSA was 9.88, 9 of 12 cores were positive, tumor involvement ran from 10-95%, and have family history of PCa. He stated that while we might not be in a big rush to do anything, we needed to come up with some plan for the future. Spent the next hour discussing and explaining AS, surgery, and radiation. Thought he did an excellent job in explaining them all, giving me names of what he thought were excellent Dr in each field, and did not seem to pushing any one over the other. Told him of the options given, at that time I was leaning toward AS or surgery. Again he stated that we did not have to make decision immediately and that he would like to run an OncotypeDx test which might make decisions easier. Told us it would take around 2 weeks to hear back on OncotypeDx and that would give my wife and I time to think about choices available before meeting with him again. So that is where we are now. Have spent a great deal of time talking to other Pca patients about thier choice of treatment and outcomes, reading what I can find on internet,,and of course spent hours here seeing what other guys thoughts and results are. This is where I start feeling like that squirrel trying to cross a busy street. Do I stay where I am keeping an eye on everything, or make a dash across the street and hope I don't get hit. My thought process to this point has me running in one direction, and then just as quickly heading of in another direction. You guys and gals seem to have excellent insight, so hopefully you can see something in reports to date that might get me headed in the right direction. Thanks, Denny
Posts.Signature: DOB - 07/05/1949 Age-68 PCa Family History - Father, Paternal Uncle (Both died from cardiac issues) PSA- 1997-2013 Gradually increasing from 1.4 - 3.2, PSA 2014 3.5 PSA 2015 4.7 PSA 06/08/2017 8.8 PSA 07/19/2017 9.88 DRE-smooth, normal Biopsy - 08/15/2017 Biopsy results: 9 of 12 cores positive - Gleason 6 - Percent Tumor Involvement 10-95% Left mid Prostate - Adenocarcinoma of prostate.
